results.title: Total eclipse
results.creator_credit: Agnieszka Holland, Jean-Pierre Ramsay-Levi, Portman Productions and FIT Production
results.brief_description: Agnieszka Holland’s (‘Europa, Europa’) excessive tale about the destructive and passionate affair between French poets Arthur Rimbaud (Leonardo DiCaprio) and Paul Verlaine (David Thewlis) is an intense study of genius and the sometimes maddening nature of creativity. Written by Christopher Hampton (‘Dangerous Liaisons’), ‘Total eclipse’ portrays the two men as being narcissistic sadists, who only take time out from torturing each other in order to torment Verlaine’s timid and unfortunate wife (Romane Bohringer). Cast also includes Dominique Blanc.

results.title: Small soldiers
results.creator_credit: Joe Dante, Michael Finnell, Colin Wilson, NBCUniversal and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: When defence industry firm Globotech takes over the small toy company Heartland Play Systems, it makes for some interesting merging of ideas. New CEO Gil Mars (Denis Leary) approves an enhancement to current action figures to make them look more realistic, and gives the task to Heartland employees Larry Benson (Jay Mohr) and Irwin Wayfair (David Cross). This results in the creation of some serious looking fighting figures, appropriately called the Command Elite who wage a constant war against the alien Gorgonites. As a final measure, Benson inserts some of Globotech’s powerful military computer chips into the new toys. In a run down toy store in Ohio, a father and son get to see the new product and decide it’s just what they need to boost their failing business. The son learns to communicate with the leader of the Gorgonites, Archer (voice supplied by Frank Langella), which has serious consequences for their future. It’s not long before the Command Elite burst forth from their packing, led by Chip Hazard (voice supplied by Tommy Lee Jones), ready as ever to do battle with the Gorgonites. When Chip sees the Gorgonite leader communicating with humans, it results in an all out war between the Command Elite and humans in a fantastic mix of live action, animatronics, puppetry and computer animation. Voices from Robert Aldrich’s ‘The Dirty Dozen’ are provided as some of the voices of the Command Elite. Cast also includes Kirsten Dunst and Gregory Smith. Features a tribute to Phil Hartman after the closing credits.

results.title: Wild reeds = Les Roseaux sauvages
results.creator_credit: Andre Techine, Georges Benayoun, Alain Sarde, Canal+, Les Films Alain Sarde and Ima Films
results.brief_description: It is 1962 and at a boarding school in rural France two young men from vastly different worlds - Francois is an urban intellectual and Serge is a farmer’s son - begin a tentative friendship. Both boys find themselves attracted to Maite, their school teacher’s daughter, but Francois must also deal with the first awakening of homosexual desire for his best friend. Their innocence is shattered by the arrival of the Algerian born Henri who brings with him the militant racist anger of the colonial expatriate, an anger he directs against his fellow school mates and towards the Communist sympathising Maite. Techine’s “Wild reeds” is possibly the defining work of French cinema at the end of the twentieth century. In setting his story in the early sixties, Techine is both acknowledging the debt owed to the Nouvelle Vague (in particular to Truffaut), as well as firmly establishing through his mise-en-scene his debt to the older, neglected French tradition of directors such as Renoir, Carne and Clair. Even though the film itself is vastly enjoyable as a narrative of adolescent rites of passage, it can also be read as an attempt to re-interrogate the cultural and historical legacy of French decolonisation and of the generation of 1968; the generation whose work and ideologies were to overwhelm French cinema and aesthetics for over two decades. “Wild reeds”, like “La haine”, “World without pity” and “Irma Vep”, is a sign of the renewal of French cinema - the exploration of new terrain and the possible reconciliation of past struggles and disruptions. This is a wonderful film. The outstanding cinematography is by Jeanne Lapoirie. The cast include Elodie Bouchez, Gael Morel, Stephane Rideau and Frederic Gorny. (Awards: Winner of the Cesar for Best Film and Best Director, 1995)

results.title: Gidget goes Hawaiian
results.creator_credit: Paul Wendkos, Jerry Bresler, Jerry Bresler Productions and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Francie Lawrence, better known as Gidget, is off on a Hawaiian holiday with her parents after being disappointed in love by her surfing boyfriend, Moondoggie. Gidget manages to conquer the boys on Waikiki with her good looks, dancing ability and naturally, her surfing prowess, but complications ensue when Moondoggie arrives unannounced. Gidget finds herself caught in a love triangle involving Moondoggie and newcomer dancing stud, Eddie Horner. Things get even worse when jealous rival, Abbey, starts a vicious rumour about Gidget having had “an unfortunate experience”, which causes an even bigger stir with her parents. Cast includes Deborah Walley, James Darren and Michael Callan.

results.title: The Witches of Eastwick
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Peter Guber, Neil Canton, Guber-Peters Company and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: In a sleepy new England town, three women- Alex, Jane and Sukie (Cher, Susan Sarandon, Michelle Pfeiffer) gather each Thursday to drink, lament the lack of eligible bachelors in their neighbourhood, and fanstasize about their dream partner. Enter wealthy and attractive Daryl van Horne (Jack Nicholson) whom they have innocently conjured up; unbeknownst to them he is the devil in disguise. It’s not long before Daryl has slept with Alex, Jane and Sukie and the town gossip starts- spear headed by local busy body Felicia Alden (Veronica Cartwright), who soon has a nasty experience with some cherries. The women begin to suspect they are not dealing with no ordinary man and must combine their reinvigorated female energy to defeat Satan himself in the ultimate battle of the sexes. Based on the book by John Updike.

results.title: You've got mail
results.creator_credit: Nora Ephron, Lauren Shuler and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This story brings romance and courtship (as well as Meg Ryan, Tom Hanks and director Nora Ephron for the third time) into the age of the World Wide Web via email and chat rooms. Joe and Kathleen have a lot in common, they live near each other, they are both in the publishing industry, he in supersized book department stores - Foxbooks, and she in a small independent one - Shop Around the Corner, they even buy coffee at the same place. They have not met in person as yet, but they have met one another in a chat room where they bare their thoughts about life, work and their significant others who are less than perfect. Pretty soon NY152 and Shop Girl want to meet in person, which leads to inevitable angst when two soul mates discover they are business rivals. Cast also includes Parker Posey and Greg Kinnear.

results.title: Starship troopers
results.creator_credit: Paul Verhoeven, Jon Davison, Alan Marshall, Tri-Star Pictures and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Presented as an enthusiastic, squeaky clean propaganda/soap opera style film, this highly satirical work from director Paul Verhoeven is an effective political comment on militaristic and colonialistic driven societies. Johnny Rico (Casper Van Dien) and his unquestioningly patriotic friends; recent graduates of the Buenos Aires High School, join the Federation forces in a mission to the home planet of an alien bug race that threatens life on earth. What follows is an amazing epic science fiction adventure complete with love triangle, mock news flashes, schlock battle sequences and seamless special effects as the all too mannequin-like characters attempt to overcome their vicious bug enemies. Cast includes Casper Van Dien, Denise Richards, Jake Busey, Neil Patrick Harris, Patrick Muldoon and Michael Ironside. Based on the book by Robert A. Heinlein.

results.title: Babe: pig in the city
results.brief_description: The sequel to the 1995 surprise hit ‘Babe’ moves the action of the first film into the vast unknown of a sprawling metropolis. Along with the radical change comes a surprisingly dark undertone. What launches Babe’s adventure is an unfortunate well accident involving farmer Hoggett. Babe, along with Mrs Hoggett, must then head into the big city to drum up money and save the farm from bankruptcy. Once there the native duo are separated and Babe finds himself in a strange boarding house for animals. Although critics feared the film might have been too intense for kids, Miller’s film is full of compassion, pathos and unexpected poignanacy.

results.title: Alien resurrection
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Walter Hill, David Giler, Gordon Carroll, Bill Badalato and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Sigourney Weaver reprises her role as Ellen Ripley, a big surprise to most fans considering she died at the end of ‘Alien 3’. In this next instalment of the series a group of scientists succeed in resurrecting Ripley by cloning her. Their main motivation being the Queen Alien which lies dormant within her DNA. Science runs amok however when the alien terror is unwittingly unleased on the scientists spacecraft. The newly revived Ripley (who is a different creature in many respects from her past incarnation), must join forces with a group of smugglers and a mysterious young mechanic named Call (Winona Ryder) to combat the vicious aliens. The strength of the alien saga has always been the constantly evolving character of Ripley and the fresh perspective different creative talents have brought to the series. (Ridley Scott directed the first one, James Cameron the second and David Fincher the third). In this fourth instalment, director Jean-Piere Jeunet (‘City of lost children’, ‘Delicatessen’) populates the film with surreal, womb like imagery, plenty of visceral thrills and a magnificent action sequence set underwater. Cast also includes Ron Perlman, Dan Hedaya, Brad Dourif, Michael Wincott and J.E. Freeman.

results.title: Tank girl
results.creator_credit: Rachel Talalay, John Watson, Pen Densham, Richard Lewis, Trilogy Entertainment Group and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: The year is 2033 and water is a precious commodity. In the desolate wind swept plains, animals are banned, bathing is unheard of, and the Water & Power Company, headed by the villainous Kesslee (Malcolm McDowell), have ultimate control over the precious H20. One rebel girl stands in their way, Rebecca (Lori Petty), a chick with attitude and an outrageous hairstyle. She is captured by Water & Power when they kill her boyfriend, kidnap her young friend, and try to blackmail her into joining their team. As a prisoner Rebecca discovers a new passion- tanks, and makes a friend with mechanic and pilot, Jet Girl (Naomi Watts), who helps her escape. Once free the girls join forces with The Rippers, an army of half men and half kangaroos, genetically modified to be the ultimate fighting machines. Together they take Water & Power head on, lead by Jet Girl in the sky, and tank girl on the ground with her beloved tank in a flurry of live action and comic strip visuals. Cast also includes Ice-T, Don Harvey and Jeff Kober.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rachel Talalay, John Watson, Pen Densham, Richard Lewis, Trilogy Entertainment Group and United Artists Corporation
